item.title: 2016 US Election
item.description: 2016 California Contributors In this post we are going to examine contributions made to Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump in the state of California before the 2016 US primary elections. The traditionally blue state went was clearly won by the democrats and their nominee Hillary Clinton. Preparing the Data We start with loading the data. CA_contributors_2016 <- vroom::vroom(here::here("content", "blogs","data","CA_contributors_2016.csv")) # Loading Contribution Data Set zip_codes_data <- vroom::vroom("http://www.uszipcodelist.com/zip_code_database.csv") # inspecting the data sets glimpse(CA_contributors_2016) ## Rows: 1,292,843 ## Columns: 4 ## $ cand_nm <chr> "Clinton, Hillary Rodham", "Clinton, Hillary Rodh.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Analyzing US highschool health
item.description: categories: - "" - "" date: “2020-20-09” description: Analyzing health patterns among US highschoolers draft: false image: volleyball.jpg keywords: "" slug: health_data title: Analyzing US highschool health Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance Every two years, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention conduct the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS) survey, where it takes data from high schoolers (9th through 12th grade), to analyze health patterns. In the following we will conduct various health-related analysis.

item.title: Bike Rentals London
item.description: Excess rentals in TfL bike sharing In this post we ar going to use the TfL data on how many bikes were hired in London every single day. We can get the latest data by running the following piece of code ## Response [https://airdrive-secure.s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/london/dataset/number-bicycle-hires/2020-09-18T09%3A06%3A54/tfl-daily-cycle-hires.xlsx?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=AKIAJJDIMAIVZJDICKHA%2F20200920%2Feu-west-1%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20200920T212831Z&X-Amz-Expires=300&X-Amz-Signature=9b012bf1ff2cb2113c6ca533d6c4a94604e76434a90a54f55a41b3aaed65d518&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host] ## Date: 2020-09-20 21:29 ## Status: 200 ## Content-Type: application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet ## Size: 165 kB ## <ON DISK> C:\Users\jacam\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpWmfCcx\file388c4ab7787d.xlsx ## Rows: 3,686 ## Columns: 2 ## $ Day <dttm> 2010-07-30, 2010-07-31, 2010-08-01, 2010.

item.title: Predicting AIRBNB prices
item.description: Executive Summary In this post, we analyse listings from Airbnb bookings (via insideairbnb.com) to better understand price patterns within a particular city. The city we examined was Cape Town and we tried to predict the total cost of four nights for two people To kick things off, we performed EDA to examine the data in more detail. Next, we subset the data and performed feature engineering to create new features which may suitable for further modeling.
